digest.editor_note: Fellow Humans, the day's most telling story isn't a market number — it's La Caisse de Depot quietly flagging that appetite for American assets 'could diminish' while sitting on C$517 billion and an AI concentration risk that accounts for as much as 20% of the S&P 500. Meanwhile, Circle just posted 77% revenue growth on stablecoin demand, proving that somewhere in this muddled macro picture, someone is making money — just not necessarily in the places the last cycle trained us to look.

sentiment.label: Cautious
sentiment.context: La Caisse's underperformance versus benchmark, AI valuation concentration warnings, and luxury consumer strain signal a market navigating genuine structural uncertainty rather than clean risk appetite.

stories.headline: La Caisse Returns 9.3% but Misses Benchmark, Warns on US Asset Concentration
stories.body: Canada's second-largest pension fund reported C$517 billion in net assets after a 9.3% return in 2025, trailing its 10.9% benchmark — dragged by private equity gains of just 2.3% and US dollar depreciation. CEO Charles Emond warned that AI concentration risk may represent up to 20% of S&P 500 pricing and said policy instability could erode global appetite for American assets. The fund is actively reducing equity exposure and rotating toward credit.

stories.headline: Circle Shares Surge 23% After Q4 Revenue Jumps 77% on USDC Stablecoin Demand
stories.body: Circle reported fourth-quarter revenue growth of 77% year-over-year, driven by USDC circulation rising 72% to a market cap of roughly $75 billion, sending shares up 23% in morning trading. The company counts Visa and Polymarket among infrastructure adopters, and is partnering with Bermuda to build the world's first fully onchain national economy. Analysts caution that rate compression and intensifying competition remain material risks to sustaining the performance.

stories.headline: Meta Takes 30% Stake in Reliance's AI Arm for Rs 256.6 Crore as Joint Venture Closes
stories.body: Reliance Industries has completed the stake allotment for its AI subsidiary Reliance Enterprise Intelligence Ltd, with Facebook Overseas — Meta's subsidiary — receiving 30% for Rs 256.6 crore and Reliance Intelligence taking the remaining 70% for Rs 596.6 crore. The JV, announced at RIL's August 2025 AGM, will leverage Meta's Llama models alongside Reliance's digital infrastructure to deliver enterprise AI services. The deal closes as the Nifty IT index has shed roughly 20% in February alone and questions mount over AI's near-term return on investment.

stories.headline: Fermi Inc. Faces Securities Class Action Over Alleged IPO Misrepresentations on AI Data Center Demand
stories.body: Law firm Hagens Berman has issued notice of a pending securities class action against Fermi Inc. (NASDAQ: FRMI), alleging the company misrepresented demand for its 'Project Matador' AI data center campus in IPO materials. The stock fell nearly 34% in December 2025 after its anchor tenant terminated a $150 million construction financing agreement. The lead plaintiff deadline is March 6, 2026, and the case targets executives, directors, and IPO underwriters.

stories.headline: Cuban Border Agents Kill Four on Florida-Tagged Speedboat in Gulf Incident
stories.body: Cuba's Interior Ministry announced that its border patrol forces killed four people and arrested six after a firefight with a speedboat bearing Florida plates off the island's north-central coast. Cuban authorities allege the vessel was carrying firearms, Molotov cocktails, and camouflage for a planned 'infiltration for terrorist purposes,' while the crew fired first. Florida's attorney general has opened a state-level investigation, and Vice President JD Vance has weighed in, ratcheting up US-Cuba tensions at an already fraught moment.

stories.headline: Luxury Retailers Recalibrate as High-Income Consumers — Nearly Half Earning $100K+ — Live Paycheck to Paycheck
stories.body: PYMNTS Intelligence data shows that nearly half of consumers earning above $100,000 annually report living paycheck to paycheck, with more than a third of those earning above $200,000 in the same position — complicating the luxury sector's reliance on affluent resilience. Brands are responding by emphasizing value narratives and payment flexibility including BNPL, as 28% of high-income shoppers report trading down on quality. Moody's Analytics chief economist Mark Zandi notes the spending gap between income cohorts 'has never been wider,' even as the top 10% account for nearly half of all US consumer spending.

stories.headline: Puerto Vallarta Airbnb Host Absorbs Cancellations After Jalisco Violence as Mexico Tourism Faces New Uncertainty
stories.body: Lora Pope, who manages three Airbnbs in Puerto Vallarta generating at least half her income, reports receiving cancellations following recent cartel violence in Jalisco — a region historically considered among Mexico's safest tourist corridors. Pope, who was in Mexico City during the incident, kept guests informed and says bookings have since recovered, but the episode marks a new category of operational risk for short-term rental operators in Mexican resort markets. The incident adds pressure to Mexico's tourism-dependent economy already navigating heightened scrutiny from US trade and diplomatic tensions.

quote.text: The four most dangerous words in investing are: 'This time it's different.'
quote.attribution: Sir John Templeton, speech to the World Economic Forum, 1994
